newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Luxembourg PM does not see EMU threat to economy.
newsitem.headline: Luxembourg PM does not see EMU threat to economy.

text.p: Luxembourg Prime Minister Jean-Claude Juncker said on Friday he did not see the advent of a single European currency destroying the Grand Duchy's financial centre, which is the cornerstone of its economy.

"The financial centre has proved flexible and adaptable to new realitites," Juncker told Reuters at a meeting of European Union leaders, called to broker a deal on EU institutional reform. "Maybe some bankers will have a less easy life, but I am not paid to make life easy for them."
Juncker noted that once economic and monetary union starts Luxembourg would become a "co-owner" of one of the greatest currencies in the world.
"The banks have simply to adapt," Juncker said.
At present, Luxembourg's currency, the franc, has the same value as the Belgian franc and exchange rate policy is managed by the National Bank of Belgium.
Luxembourg, the European Union's smallest member state, has around 220 banks -- one for every 2,000 inhabitants -- managing one of Europe's largest mutual fund industries.
